The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Klein Four-Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Klein Four-Group explicitly states that it is a subgroup of the symmetric group $\\frak{S}_{4}$. This implies that the concept of the symmetric group must be understood first in order to comprehend what $\\frak{S}_{4}$ represents, as it refers to the group of all permutations of four elements. Without understanding what a symmetric group is, one cannot fully grasp the structure or the elements of the Klein Four-Group, since its elements are described as specific permutations within $\\frak{S}_{4}$. Therefore, the concept of a symmetric group is necessary to define and understand the Klein Four-Group.
